subject: RE: [junit] Stack overflow crashes GUI test runners
msgSnippet: ... Point taken ;) -Eric __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? Yahoo! Sports - live college hoops coverage http://sports.yahoo.com/
messageBody:
--- Theodore Norvell <theo@...> wrote:
> Nevertheless JUnit does a fine job of catching,
> logging, and recovering
> from the first stack overflow. Presumably the stack
> is unwound as an
> exception handler is hunted for, freeing up stack
> space. It is the
> second stack overflow in the same suite that causes
> the problem. If the
> suite only has one error, then that suite can be run
> multiple times.
>
> > The JVM should never crash though, in the sense of
> a core dump. If it
> > does, it's likely a JVM bug.
>
> Thanks for the suggestion. This turned out to be
> correct. The
> JVM in question is JDK 1.3.1 for Windows. Turning
> off compilation
> (option -Xint) eliminated the problem, as did using
> jview; JUnit
> correctly reported both errors under those
> circumstances.
>
> On Thu, 14 Mar 2002, Eric Heikkila wrote:
> > Kind of sounds like a non-issue. Fix the stack
> > overflows. ;)
>
> If I didn't have bugs, I wouldn't need JUnit. :-)
>
> More seriously, using JUnit did reveal the bug; it
> just did so in the
> rather abrupt manner of crashing. I'd prefer to see
> a red-line and a
> message. However, you are right, it is not an issue
> for me. At first I
> thought that the problem might be in the custom
> implementation of the Test
> interface that I was using to bridge between JUnit
> and a test framework I
> am developing. Had that been the case, I would have
> had an issue. Once I
> was able to duplicate the problem with a standard
> TestCase, it was clear
> that the problem wasn't in my code, and thus not a
> problem for me.
> However the strange behaviour did suggest a bug in
> JUnit, which might be
> an issue of interest to those who develop JUnit.
> But I should have
> thought of the possibility that it was the JVM at
> fault.
>
> Cheers,
> Theodore Norvell
>


Point taken ;)

-Eric
